> This may sound strange, but it also might be useful to define an
> altern=
ative XML syntax for sheets. The translation would be very
> simple, and wo=
uld not need to happen in Heritrix itself. For instance:
>
> <sheet>
>   <e=
ntry key=3D"root" type=3D"map" value=3D"java.lang.Object"/>
>   <entry key=
=3D"root:metadata" type=3D"primary"  
> value=3D"org.archive.modules.writer=
.DefaultMetadataProvider"/>
>   [=85]
> </sheet>
>
> This is not a better s=
yntax, but it could fit in with XML workflows.

Well we'd have to think abo=
ut whether we wanted to officially support  
two formats going forward.

>>=
 I should mention that, unlike in 1.x, in 2.x anything that can
>> happen i=
n the Web UI can also happen over JMX. The Web UI now uses
>> JMX exclusive=
ly to communicate with Heritrix.
>
> This is undoubtedly a good thing. Init=
ial impetus for development of
> an HTTP interface was to allow full contro=
l of Heritrix across the
> network.
>
> Personally, I still feel that JMX i=
n general is a bit clunky, and that
> an HTTP interface which mimicked the =
JMX interface would be less than
> ideal. For instance, I am note sure that=
 a readFile (job, filename,
> settingsPath, startPos, length) invocation, p=
iped through a POST, is
> the best way to get a crawl.log. I would much pre=
fer a GET on
> <http://example.org/jobs/20071211233637/crawl.log>. Addition=
ally, it
> doesn=92t appear to be possible to fetch the ARC files generated=
 by a
> crawl; indeed, JMX seems poorly disposed to handle the retrieval of=

> large files in general.

It's definitely a huge oversight that JMX can't=
 do streaming  
operations -- the web UI can only edit 32K of seeds, for in=
stance. I  
suppose we could try to extend JMX to allow streaming, but ther=
e's  
already a mountain of JMX support code in commons, and JMX is, alas, =
 
the standard.

Also for transferring large files like arcs or the crawl.l=
og, you're  
better off using NFS/SMB. I wouldn't want to integrate a full =
WebDAV  
server (say) into Heritrix to enable arc removal; those kinds of  =

tasks seem better suited to tools outside of Heritrix.

Unless you really =
do want the entire log file, you can use the  
LogRemoteAccess MBean to rea=
d the parts you're interested in.

> Ok, done. <http://webteam.archive.org/=
jira/browse/HER-1378> I attached
> a first approximation of a patch as well=
.

Thanks!

-Paul
